tool.name: NRT_Modify_Monitoring_Areas

param.name: in_feat
param.dialogReference:
Set the input monitoring area feature that holds the areas to be modified. Any feature class not created by the Create Monitoring Areas tool will be rejected.

Note: any changes made will result in the current change result being erased.

param.name: in_set_area
param.displayname: Select the monitoring area to modify
param.dialogReference: Select a specific monitoring area to modify based on its unique identifier.

param.name: in_platform
param.dialogReference: Select between Landsat or Sentinel satellite platforms as a source of monitoring data. Landsat provides 35+ years of archived data at 30 m resolution, whereas Sentinel provides 10 m resolution imagery from 2016 onwards.

param.name: in_s_year
param.dialogReference:
Set the starting year of the "pre-impact" period. The harmonic regression model will be trained from this year onwards.

Advice: selecting the correct training period is vital in deriving a accurate monitoring model. If a model is trained starting during a year of drought or excess wetness, the rest of the vegetation data will be compared to this period (unless using the dynamic model, which will re-calibrate automatically). Choose a starting period of standard, stable vegetation health.

Note: a period of two or more years (between start and end period) is required.

param.name: in_e_year
param.dialogReference:
Set the ending year of the "pre-impact" period. The harmonic regression model will be trained entirely on this period.

The model will attempt to finish at this selected year (inclusive), but may go over or under this year if need be.

Note: a period of two or more years (between start and end period) is required.

param.name: in_veg_idx
param.dialogReference:
Set the vegetation index used to derive vegetation "greeness". Options include:

- NDVI (Normalized Difference Vegetation Index)

- MAVI (Moisture-Adjusted Vegetation Index)

- kNDVI (Non-linear Normalized Vegetation Index)

param.name: in_persistence
param.dialogReference:
Persistence is best considered as the minimum number of consecutive outliers needed to register a significant deviation via the harmonic regression model.

In practical terms, a lower persistence will register a deviation quicker than a higher persistence, but will be prone to more noise (i.e., minor deviations). A higher persistence value will only register larger, more on-going changes, but may detect these later than when they begin occurring.

A value between 0.2 and 0.5 has been found to be optimal, but experimentation is required.

param.name: in_min_conseqs
param.dialogReference:
Rule 1 counts the number of consecutive increases or decreases in vegetation deviation. An alarm will only be triggered once a certain number of consecutive increases or decreases has been reached, as set here.

For example, if a value of 2 is used, an alarm will not be signaled until that decline has occurred two times in a row. A higher value will mean an alarm is only triggered when number of on-going decline has been recorded, whereas a lower value will trigger alarms very early on when trajectory trends in a specific direction.

param.name: in_inc_plateaus
param.dialogReference:
By default, the rule 1 alert system does not include "plateau values" (i.e., a period of several samples that were the exact same deviation value neither up or down).

Set this to Yes to include plateaus in the consecutive alarm trigger calculation.

param.name: in_min_zone
param.dialogReference: Set the minimum zone value allowed before a trigger is fired.

param.name: in_num_zones
param.dialogReference:
Rule 3 is used to detect sharp "spikes" in deviation jumps, if detected. The value here determines how many zones must be jumped before a trigger is registered.

The smaller the value here, the smaller the spike needs to be in order to register an alarm. Set this value higher to only register significant spikes in deviation leaps.

param.name: in_ruleset
param.expression: 1 and 2 or 3 | 1 Only | 2 Only | 3 Only | 1 and 2 | 1 and 3 | 2 and 3 | 1 or 2 | 1 or 3 | 2 or 3 | 1 and 2 and 3 | 1 or 2 and 3 | 1 or 2 or 3
param.dialogReference:
The ruleset sets the unique combinations of rules to be used for trigger alarms. The available rules include:

  • 1 Only: only rule 1 is considered

  • 2 Only: only rule 2 is considered

  • 3 Only: only rule 3 is considered

  • 1 and 2 : rule 1 and 2 are combined and considered

  • 1 and 3: rule 1 and 3 are combined and considered

  • 2 and 3: rule 2 and 3 are combined and considered

  • 1 or 2 : rule 1 or 2 are considered

  • 1 or 3 : rule 1 or 3 are considered

  • 2 or 3 : rule 2 or 3 are considered

  • 1 and 2 and 3: rules 1, 2 and 3 are combined and considered

  • 1 or 2 and 3: rules 1 or (2 and 3) are considered

  • 1 and 2 or 3: rules (1 and 2) or 3 are considered

  • 1 or 2 or 3: rules 1 or 2 or 3 are considered

The default is 1 and 2 or 3.

param.name: in_alert_user
param.dialogReference: If set to Yes, the user will obtain an email alert if an email address is provided below. Otherwise, no email will be sent.

param.name: in_alert_method
param.dialogReference:
Set whether alerts are based on the static or dynamic change algorithm methods. These methods are described as:

- Static: every new vegetation value is compared to the original training period even if these values have deviated significantly for a long period of time

- Dynamic: one a specific deviation threshold (generated by the model) has been reached, the original training period is discarded and the model chooses a new one that better represents the "new regime".

param.name: in_alert_direction
param.displayname: Direction of change to trigger alert
param.expression: Decline only (any) | Incline only (any) | Incline only (+ zones only) | Decline only (- zones only) | Incline or Decline (any) | Incline or Decline (+/- zones only)
param.dialogReference:
Set which specific type of change is allowed to trigger the alert email system. Options include:

- Incline only (any): if deviations begin to move in an upwards trajectory in wither positive or negative zones, an alert may be triggered.

- Decline only (any): if deviations begin to move in a downwards trajectory in either positive or negative zones, an alert may be triggered.

- Incline only (+ zones only): if deviations begin to move in an upwards trajectory in a positive zone, an alert may be triggered.

- Decline only (- zones only): if deviations begin to move in a downwards trajectory in a negative zone, an alert may be triggered.

- Incline or decline only (any): if deviations begin to move in an upwards or downwards trajectory in either positive or negative zones, an alert may be triggered.

- Incline or decline only (any): if deviations begin to move in an upwards or downwards trajectory in the positive or negative zones, respectively, an alert may be triggered.

param.name: in_email
param.dialogReference: Set the email address of the person who will receive trigger alerts for this monitoring area.

param.name: in_ignore_user
param.dialogReference: If set to Yes, this monitoring area will be ignored during monitoring. Useful if the monitoring area is no longer in need of monitoring but useful for historical purposes.

tool.summary:
Modify existing monitoring area features by changing their model parameters. This can be useful to refine pre-impact periods and other rules.

Note: this tool requires that a project geodatabase has been created prior using the Create Project tool and monitoring areas have been created within using the Create Monitoring Areas tool.
